data.name: Black Ant
data.food: Not picky eaters: food includes insects, nectar, fruit, dead animals, human garbage
data.habitat: Ant hills in the ground or rotted logs
funfacts: Leave a scent trail that leads other ants to a food source
Can lift 20 times its own body weight
Produce chemical alarms when threatened by an intruder
Live in organized social colonies with 3 kinds of ants: queen, female workers, and male drones
Queen is the only one that can lay eggs
Males have wings; the queen has wings only until she mates and establishes a colony; workers don’t have wings

data.name: Fire Ant
data.food: Omnivorous, will eat almost any plant or animal, alive or dead
data.habitat: Often in disturbed areas such as roadsides and recent forest clearings
funfacts: Live in large colonies of up to 250,000 worker ants
Create tunnels extending up to 25 feet from the mound
Small, very aggressive, repeatedly stinging anything that intrudes into their colonies
Grip by biting, then sting, injecting a toxin that feels like fire
Dozens, even hundreds, sting in unison
Can strip a carcass clean overnight

data.name: Bumble Bee
data.food: Flower nectar and pollen
data.habitat: Anywhere with abundant flowers
funfacts: Vibrate wing muscles so fast that flowers release their pollen (buzz pollination)
Have pollen baskets on hind legs for carrying pollen
Will scent-mark flowers so other bumble bees know the nectar is gone and not waste time looking
Efficient pollinators of crops such as blueberries and strawberries
Typically make new nests in or near the ground each spring. Only queen overwinters

data.name: Eastern Carpenter Bee
data.food: Nectar from many different flower species
data.habitat: Anywhere with abundant flowers
funfacts: Solitary, not social bees, so don’t have hives
Females chew through wood making tunnels to lay eggs
Females rarely sting; males can’t sting
Males are territorial. If you throw a rock of similar size close to them, they chase it as if a rival male
Sometimes chew through base of flowers to obtain nectar, thereby “cheating” the flower of pollination

data.name: Honey Bee
data.food: Nectar, pollen, honey
data.habitat: Anywhere with abundant flowers
funfacts: Perform a 'waggle' dance to instruct the rest of hive where to find food
Gather nectar to make honey. One teaspoon of honey takes about 154 bee trips from flowers to hive
Mix honey with pollen to make food for the larva. This sub-stance determines whether females develop into queens or workers
Barbed stinger remains attached to victim so the bee dies after stinging, unlike yellowjacket wasps

data.name: June Bug Beetle
data.food: Adults eat fruit and leaves; larvae eat plant roots
data.habitat: Grassy fields and yards
funfacts: Much bigger than Japanese Beetle
Attracted to lights at night
Can take up to 3 years to mature into adults
Clumsy fliers that often collide with people and objects
Don't sting or bite

data.name: Japanese Beetle
data.food: Adults eat leaves, flowers, and fruits of many plants, even poison ivy. Larvae eat plant roots
data.habitat: Parks, gardens, crop fields
funfacts: Major pest of garden plants and crops
Feed by 'skeletonizing' leaves, eating only the parts between the veins
Damaged plants release chemicals that attract more beetles; wind can carry odor several hundred yards
Group can strip a fruit tree of its leaves in 15 minutes

data.name: Ladybug Beetle
data.food: Smaller soft-bodied insects, such as aphids, scale insects, mites
data.habitat: Low-growing plants, wherever suitable prey is found
funfacts: Secrete a foul-smelling fluid from its leg joints when startled, scaring away predators
Larvae resemble tiny alligators
Many local ladybugs are an invasive Asian species originally imported for garden pest control
Native ladybugs overwinter under bark or leaves; Asian species may seek shelter by the thousands in your house

data.name: Firefly Beetle
data.food: Most adults do not feed. Larvae eat worms, snails, and slugs
data.habitat: Adults fly in open areas during the summer
funfacts: Signal each other with light flashes
Males signal while flying; females answer from the ground
Their light is nearly 100% light, not heat -- amazingly efficient
Larvae also glow, warning that they are not tasty and may be toxic

data.name: Tiger Beetle
data.food: Insects and spiders
data.habitat: Stream and lake edges and woodland paths
funfacts: Eat other insects, many of which harm crops
Adults are fast runners; some can run 5 mph
Larvae live in vertical tunnels, waiting for a meal. When an insect walks over the tunnel, the larva clamps its jaws on it, drags it down the hole, and eats it

data.name: Leaf-footed Bug & Stink Bug
data.size: Leaf-footed Bug: 1 - 1.3 inch; Stink Bug: 1/2 inch
data.food: Juices from various plants, including fruit and vegetable crops
data.habitat: Agricultural fields and gardens
funfacts: Both release a foul-smelling liquid if attacked or squashed, protecting them from predators
Both have sucking and piercing mouth-parts to suck plant juice
Leaf-footed bugs are named for their large, widened hind legs that resemble leaves
The Brown marmorated stink bug, an invasive species from Asia, has become common and may winter in houses

data.name: Cicada
data.food: Adults feed on plant juices; nymphs on tree roots
data.habitat: Juveniles live underground; adults live in the tops of trees
funfacts: Cicada nymphs live underground. Some emerge and shed their shells after 13 or 17 years; others emerge every year
Clumsy fliers, often bump into things, but don’t bite or sting
A chorus of cicadas can roar as loud as heavy duty power equipment, sometimes confusing cicadas who may swarm around people using lawn mowers and leaf blowers

data.name: Cockroach
data.size: Up to 2 inch depending on species
data.food: In homes: dead insects, food, paper, cloth, just about anything. In woods: decaying matter
data.habitat: Frequently found in homes, but most species live in the woods
funfacts: Believed to have evolved more than 280 million years ago
Can live for a week without its head
Can fly but rarely bother, going fastest when they run on their two hind legs
Each of their 6 legs has 3 sets of 'knees' that sense vibrations and serve as an early warning system

data.name: Cricket
data.food: Various organic matter
data.habitat: Most species live in grass; others live in bushes or trees
funfacts: Rub wings together, creating a song to attract mates
'Ears' are located on front legs
Can jump 20 to 30 times their height
Use jumping as main mode of transportation even though they have wings

data.name: Damselfly
data.size: (Double-striped Bluet above: 1 inch), 1 - 2.5 inch range for all species
data.food: Small soft-bodied insects including aphids, mosquitoes, and gnats
data.habitat: Near water
funfacts: Unlike dragonflies, damselflies are thinner and hold wings together over their bodies when at rest
Have four wings almost equal in size and shape
Stay close to water, often resting on surface vegetation
Like dragonflies, they cannot walk, but only fly and land

data.name: Dragonfly
data.size: (Common Whitetail above: 2 inch), 1.5 - 5 inch range for all species
data.food: Adults eat other flying insects, particularly mosquitoes. The larvae eat almost anything smaller than themselves, such as tadpoles
data.habitat: Usually near ponds and rivers
funfacts: Can fly up or down, backwards or forwards, stop and hover -- like a helicopter
Only eat prey caught while in mid-air. Without flying, they would starve
Have incredible vision since nearly all of its head is eye
One dragonfly can eat 30 to hundreds of mosquitoes per day

data.name: Horse Fly
data.food: Females drink blood; males drink nectar
data.habitat: Meadows and pastures with food sources
funfacts: Females feed on blood of mammals to support egg development
Once eggs hatch, the larva spend 1-2 years growing; adult horse flies only live for a few days
20-30 horse flies can drain almost 20 teaspoons of blood from victim in a single feeding
Many species have beautiful, multi-colored eyes

data.name: House Fly
data.food: Garbage, human food scraps, dead animals, anything edible
data.habitat: Anywhere humans live
funfacts: Can’t bite or chew so they vomit stomach juices on food to liquefy it, then slurp up
Lay eggs on fruit, food, other animals, and rotting flesh to provide a food source for larvae
Larvae (maggots) look like bits of rice and have no legs
Feet are 10 million times more sensitive to taste of sugar than human tongue

data.name: Hover Fly
data.food: Flower nectar or pollen
data.habitat: Anywhere with abundant flowers
funfacts: Mimic the coloring of bees or wasps to avoid predators. Example in photo mimics the yellowjacket
Some species sneak into bumble bee nests and lay eggs. Once hatched, larvae feed on dead bees
Can fly backwards; do not sting or bite
One hover fly larva can consume the body fluids of hundreds of aphids (common garden pests)

data.name: Grasshopper
data.size: (American Birdwing above: 2.8 inch), 1 - 5 inch range for all species
data.food: Crop plants, grasses, and weeds
data.habitat: Dry open spaces
funfacts: Rub hind legs against forewings to make a singing sound
'Ears' are on their bellies
Back legs act like miniature catapults enabling them to leap long distances
Existed long before dinosaurs
Sometimes spit brown liquid to defend themselves

data.name: Katydid
data.food: Mainly tree leaves. Some also eat other insects
data.habitat: Bushes and tops of deciduous trees, especially oaks
funfacts: Named for night call, which sounds like 'Ka-ty-did'
Mimic leaves with green color and wing veins
Sing to each other by rubbing front wings together
Hear with 'ears' on front legs that move to hear in any direction
Can jump up to 20 times their body length

data.name: Praying Mantis
data.size: (Chinese Mantis above: 3 - 4.5 inch), 2 - 4.5 inch range for all species
data.food: Insects, spiders, frogs, lizards, small birds, and each other
data.habitat: Open fields, forest edges, and gardens
funfacts: Capable of turning its head 180 degrees around its body
Females sometimes eat the male after mating
Named for their front legs, which they hold in a way that resembles praying
Commonly seen species have been introduced for pest control but are now outcompeting native praying mantises

data.name: Mosquito
data.food: Males and females feed on plant nectar; females of many species drink blood to produce eggs
data.habitat: Varies, but never far from water where they lay eggs
funfacts: Can carry diseases that cause more human deaths than any other animal
Only females bite. Abdomens can expand with blood up to 3 times their body weight
Locate blood by detecting carbon dioxide exhaled by humans and animals from up to 100 feet away
Eggs can survive for up to 5 years before hatching

data.name: Hummingbird Clearwing Moth
data.food: Caterpillars feed on dogbane, honeysuckle, and snowberry. Adults feed on nectar
data.habitat: Meadows, parks, and gardens
funfacts: Smaller by 1 - 2 inches than hummingbirds with six, long visible legs
Mimic small hummingbirds; can move forwards, sideways, and backwards
Hover by moving their wings in a figure 8 pattern at 85 wingbeats per second, creating an audible hum
One of the few moths that flies during the day

data.name: Luna Moth
data.food: Adults do not feed. Caterpillars eat the leaves of many trees
data.habitat: Hardwood trees in forests, suburbs, and parks
funfacts: Adults can’t feed because they lack a mouth. Only live about one week
Females lay as many as 200 eggs on the undersides of leaves
Favorite snack for bats. Moths’ constant twirling disorients bats, helping moths escape
Active only at night

data.name: Paper Wasp
data.food: Grasshoppers, aphids, flies, bees, nectar, tree sap, fruit
data.habitat: Forest edges, meadows. Often build their nests on wooden structures like houses
funfacts: Make nests by chewing up strips of bark, spitting it out to make a rough paper
Colonies contain 20 - 75 adults
Hunt and eat almost every insect pest that harms crops
Can sting repeatedly with barbless stinger
All die in the fall except for a few new queens

data.name: Yellowjacket Wasp
data.food: Nectar, other insects, meat, garbage, fruit
data.habitat: Nests mainly underground
funfacts: Only queens survive the winter
Aggressive; barbless stinger allows them to sting multiple times, unlike honey bees
If attacked or killed, releases odor alerting other wasps to come to its aid
Many insects mimic their color and pattern to scare predators

data.name: Water Strider
data.food: Insects on the surface of water
data.habitat: The surface of ponds, lakes, edges of rivers, and streams
funfacts: Can 'walk' on the surface of water
Rear legs are used for steering and braking; middle legs act like paddles; short front legs grab prey
Use water surface tension to keep from sinking
Ripples on the surface of water help locate insect meals
